Here is a scripture we've all looked at before, but that just nags at me all 
the time. Hebrews 6:4-6. Now, I'll start with the calvinist/once saved always 
saved defense. The idea is that each individual description isn't conclusive 
in proving that the author is talking about true Christians. They will cite 
Saul who had the spirit of God and spoke by it, but was not saved. And they 
will say that partaking of any of these things was a by product of being in 
community with other believers. But for me, since the author didn't just 
mention one description of who he was talking about but 7 different 
descriptions. Let's enumerate using the ESV (one of my favourite more word 
for word translations);

1. those who have once been enlightened
2. who have tasted the heavenly gift
3. have shared the holy spirit
4. tasted the goodness of the word of God
5. and the powers of the age to come
6. and then have fallen
7. restore again.

One of the arguments is that tasting the heavenly gift is akin to the
 nonstarters in the sewn seed parable, but then the author goes on to 
include tasting the goodness of the word of God, which therefore makes 
the first idea rather moot. The combination of all of those idea's seems 
pretty sufficient evidence that the author is not speaking of non-Christians. 
Otherwise it seems to be quite a bit of overkill. The idea that they be 
restored AGAIN to repentance? You can repent more than once? The author’s 
point is either that it is impossible for someone to be a true Christian, 
reject God and then return to salvation, or his point is that it is impossible 
for someone to fake being a Christian, to not truly be saved, then turn his 
back and then become either A: a fake Christian Or B: a real Christian. So
 by once saved always saved interpretation the author is saying false 
Christians can never turn away from their empty professions, and return 
to them or they can’t turn away from their empty misunderstood professions 
and then at a later stage receive true repentance. Which seems unlikely. 
The more likely here is that the author means a person cannot return to 
Christianity once they reject it, which is why it says “return to repentance”.
 John Wesleys notes on the text seem to agree. 

“With the light of the glorious love of God in Christ. And have tasted the 
heavenly gift - Remission of sins, sweeter than honey and the honeycomb. And
 been made partakers of the Holy Ghost - Of the witness and the fruit of he 
Spirit.
Have had a relish for, and a delight in it. And the powers of the world to 
come - Which every one tastes, who has an hope full of immortality. Every 
child that is naturally born, first sees the light, then receives and tastes 
proper nourishment, and partakes of the things of this world. In like manner,
 the apostle, comparing spiritual with natural things, speaks of one born of 
the Spirit, as seeing the light, tasting the sweetness, and partaking of the 
things "of the world to come."
Here is not a supposition, but a plain relation of fact. The apostle here
 describes the case of those who have cast away both the power and the form 
of godliness; who have lost both their faith, hope, and love, Heb_6:10, &c., 
and that wilfully, Heb_10:26. Of these wilful total apostates he declares, 
it is impossible to renew them again to repentance. (though they were renewed
 once,) either to the foundation, or anything built thereon. Seeing they 
crucify the Son of God afresh - They use him with the utmost indignity. 
And put him to an open shame - Causing his glorious name to be blasphemed.”

I think the tough thing in all this is to make sense of it all. There are obviously scriptures people use on both sides to support their camp. Does that then mean the Bible contradicts itself? Does the Bible teach both eternal security and the ability to loose your salvation.

On the extreme on both sides I think there lies error. Either you think you cannot loose and live a life of willful sin or you live in fear of loosing your salvation and live a life of empty works.

What is interesting to me though, is I see people on both sides living in the middle somehow. People that believe they cannot loose their salvation and out of love and wonderment they live life full of faithful works and I see people that believe they can loose their salvation living without fear that they are on the edge of the cutting board.

My current camp is it seems to me I cannot loose my salvation as I did nothing for it. I trust my Saviour to keep me. Problem then is I need to make sense of these verses that seems to point to me being able to loose it.

That is hard I have to admit. What I find strange though is those in the other camp seem to not think it's hard. We can loose our salvation so shape up buddy. Do your spiritual push-ups. Those verses you use mean nothing... look at mine!

It does not seem to be the rest that I think our salvation should have in Jesus?

I said I'd stay out of this...I lied.....

Ok, just a comment on doing nothing for your salvation - not technically true. Because you DO have to accept the gift of salvation....otherwise we're drifting into the 'everybody saved' territory. It does need a response.

I agree with the concern over the ease of losing salvation - that then results in works focused salvation, which is wrong.

According to my understanding there is 1 thing that can lose you salvation:
"Truly I tell you, people can be forgiven all their sins and every slander they utter, but whoever blasphemes against the Holy Spirit will never be forgiven; they are guilty of an eternal sin.” Mark 3 : 28-29
&
"For it is impossible to bring back to repentance those who were once enlightened—those who have experienced the good things of heaven and shared in the Holy Spirit, who have tasted the goodness of the word of God and the power of the age to come—and who then turn away from God. It is impossible to bring such people back to repentance; by rejecting the Son of God, they themselves are nailing him to the cross once again and holding him up to public shame." Hebrews 6:4-6

I believe these two passages speak of the same thing. Direct rejection of Jesus and thus of God. Hard to imagine a true believer doing this, but the writer of Hebrews seemed to think it happens. 

Our choice to accept or reject God does not disappear after that first saving moment. Otherwise it would be pointless. It just becomes harder to do the more we learn and know God - til it seems impossible to us.

@pevans_om I though "blasphemes against the Holy Spirit" was that they were saying that the work Jesus performed was by the power of Satan? They were saying He was doing His work by an "unclean spirit" when in fact it was The Holy Spirit.

@penkin Yes, I've heard that explanation too. But it boils down to the same thing. Direct rejection of God. I can't help but feel the similarities with Hebrews when you see the dire consequences of the action is the same.
